body:
[![Docs](https://img.shields.io/badge/docs-available-brightgreen.svg)](https://r00ster91.github.io/lime/)

# lime

A library for drawing graphics on the console screen

## Features

* Drawing of
  * PNG images
  * text
  * rectangles
  * filled rectangles
  * circles
  * lines
* Non-blocking key input
* Management of the window and cursor

## Installation

Add this to your application's `shard.yml`:

```yaml
dependencies:
  lime:
    github: r00ster91/lime
```

Then run `shards install`.

## Example

Three lights flashing repeatedly in order:

```crystal
require "lime"

# Make drawables like Rectangle, Circle available
require "lime/drawables"
include Lime::Drawables

# Create the lights:
# they are red, green and blue rectangles with doubled lines
light1 = Rectangle.new(
  x: 2, y: 1,
  width: 5, height: 3,
  type: Double, color: :red
)
light2 = Rectangle.new(8, 1, 5, 3, Double, :green)
light3 = Rectangle.new(14, 1, 5, 3, Double, :blue)

# The light that is currently on
active = 1

loop do
  if active == 3
    active = 1
  else
    active += 1
  end

  case active
  when 1
    light1.color = :light_red
    light2.color = :green
    light3.color = :blue
  when 2
    light1.color = :red
    light2.color = :light_green
    light3.color = :blue
  when 3
    light1.color = :red
    light2.color = :green
    light3.color = :light_blue
  end

  # Insert the lights into the buffer:
  light1.draw
  light2.draw
  light3.draw

  # Draw the content of the buffer to the screen:
  Lime.draw
  # Clear the buffer so we have room for new stuff:
  Lime.clear

  # You can use `Lime.loop` instead of a normal loop to skip the above two steps

  sleep 0.5
end
```

In the top left corner we can see:

![lights](https://i.imgur.com/hDHDiJB.gif)

See [`examples/`](https://github.com/r00ster91/lime/tree/master/examples) for more examples.

types.name: Lime
types.doc:
The main module of lime.

All x, y arguments are zero-based.

Sometimes you may come across the terms "cell" and "pixel":
* A "cell" refers to one place of a character on the console: `█`.
* A "pixel" **does not** refer to a pixel of a display.
  It refers to the **half** of a "cell": `▀`, `▄`.

instance_methods.name: buffer
instance_methods.doc: Returns the buffer as a string.

def.name: buffer
def.body:
String.build do |io|
  @@buffer.each do |char|
    io << char
  end
end

instance_methods.name: check_key
instance_methods.doc:
Checks if a key is pressed.
Returns
- `:up` if up arrow has been pressed.
- `:down` if down arrow has been pressed.
- `:left` if left arrow has been pressed.
- `:right` if right arrow has been pressed.
- `:enter` if enter has been pressed.
- `:tab` if tab has been pressed.
- `:backspace` if backspace has been pressed.
- `:escape` if escape has been pressed.
- `:ctrl_c` if Ctrl+C has been pressed.

If none of the above keys are pressed, the key is returned as is.

If no key is pressed, returns `nil`.

def.name: check_key
def.body:
case key = check_key_raw
when "\e[A"
  :up
when "\e[B"
  :down
when "\e[C"
  :right
when "\e[D"
  :left
when "\r", "\n"
  :enter
when "\t"
  :tab
when "\u007F", "\b"
  :backspace
when "\e"
  :escape
when "\u0003"
  :ctrl_c
else
  key
end

instance_methods.name: check_key_raw
instance_methods.doc: Checks if a key is pressed, if it is, returns it, otherwise returns `nil`.
instance_methods.summary: Checks if a key is pressed, if it is, returns it, otherwise returns nil.

def.name: check_key_raw
def.body:
STDIN.raw do |io|
  begin
    io.read_timeout = 0.1
    buffer = Bytes.new(3)
    String.new(buffer[0, io.read(buffer)])
  rescue IO::Timeout
  ensure
    io.read_timeout = nil
  end
end

instance_methods.name: line
instance_methods.doc:
Inserts a line from *x1*, *y1* to *x2*, *y2* with *color* into the buffer.

This method uses [Bresenham's line algorithm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bresenham%27s_line_algorithm).
instance_methods.summary: Inserts a line from x1, y1 to x2, y2 with color into the buffer.
instance_methods.args_string: (x1 : Int32, y1 : Int32, x2 : Int32, y2 : Int32, color : Colorize::Color = Colorize::ColorANSI::Default)

def.name: line
def.body:
if (y2 - y1).abs < (x2 - x1).abs
  if x2 > x2
    Lime.line_low(x2, y2, x1, y1, color)
  else
    Lime.line_low(x1, y1, x2, y2, color)
  end
else
  if y1 > y2
    Lime.line_high(x2, y2, x1, y1, color)
  else
    Lime.line_high(x1, y1, x2, y2, color)
  end
end

instance_methods.name: loop
instance_methods.doc:
Like a game loop.
The order is as follows:

**1.** Executes the given block.

**2.** Draws the buffer to the screen.

**3.** Clears the buffer.

instance_methods.name: pixel
instance_methods.doc: Inserts a pixel at *x*, *y* with *color* into the buffer.
instance_methods.summary: Inserts a pixel at x, y with color into the buffer.
instance_methods.args_string: (x : Int32, y : Int32, color : Colorize::Color = Colorize::ColorANSI::Default)

def.name: pixel
def.body:
position = x + ((y / 2) * Window.width_cells)
if color == Colorize::ColorANSI::Default
  default_pixel(position, y)
  return
end
@@buffer[position] = (if y.even?
  if @@buffer[position].to_s.includes?('▄')
    if char = @@buffer[position].as?(Colorize::Object(Char))
      char.back(color)
    else
      (@@buffer[position].as(Char)).colorize.back(color)
    end
  else
    if char = @@buffer[position].as?(Colorize::Object(Char))
      ('▀'.colorize(color)).back(char.back)
    else
      '▀'.colorize(color)
    end
  end
else
  if @@buffer[position].to_s.includes?('▀')
    if char = @@buffer[position].as?(Colorize::Object(Char))
      char.back(color)
    else
      (@@buffer[position].as(Char)).colorize.back(color)
    end
  else
    if char = @@buffer[position].as?(Colorize::Object(Char))
      ('▄'.colorize(color)).back(char.back)
    else
      '▄'.colorize(color)
    end
  end
end)

instance_methods.name: print

instance_methods.name: print
instance_methods.doc: Inserts *string* into the buffer at *x*, *y*.

def.name: print
def.body:
string.each_char_with_index do |char, i|
  @@buffer[(x + i) + (Window.width_cells * y)] = char
end

instance_methods.name: print
instance_methods.doc: Inserts *string* into the buffer at *x*, *y*.

def.name: print
def.body:
fore = string.fore
back = string.back
string = string.to_s
if (fore == Colorize::ColorANSI::Default) && (back == Colorize::ColorANSI::Default)
  Lime.print(string, x, y)
else
  string = string[((string.index('m')).not_nil! + 1)..((string.rindex('\e')).not_nil! - 1)]
  string.each_char_with_index do |char, i|
    @@buffer[(x + i) + (y * Window.width_cells)] = (char.colorize.fore(fore)).back(back)
  end
end

instance_methods.name: printf
instance_methods.doc:
Inserts *string* formatted into the buffer at *x*, *y*.

This method properly handles newlines in the string unlike `print`:
```
Lime.printf("hello\nworld", 2, 2)
```
```text


    hello
    world
```

def.name: printf
def.body:
i = 0
string.each_line do |line|
  Lime.print(line, x, y + i)
  i = i + 1
end

instance_methods.name: printf
instance_methods.doc:
Inserts *string* formatted into the buffer at *x*, *y*.

This method properly handles newlines in the string unlike `print`:
```
Lime.printf("hello\nworld", 2, 2)
```
```text


    hello
    world
```

def.name: printf
def.body:
fore = string.fore
back = string.back
string = string.to_s
if (fore == Colorize::ColorANSI::Default) && (back == Colorize::ColorANSI::Default)
  Lime.printf(string, x, y)
else
  string = string[((string.index('m')).not_nil! + 1)..((string.rindex('\e')).not_nil! - 1)]
  i = 0
  string.each_line do |line|
    Lime.print((line.colorize.fore(fore)).back(back), x, y + i)
    i = i + 1
  end
end

instance_methods.name: draw
instance_methods.doc:
Inserts the circle into the buffer.

This method uses the [midpoint circle algorithm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Midpoint_circle_algorithm).

def.name: draw
def.body:
x1 = @radius
y1 = 0
err = -@radius
while x1 >= y1
  Lime.pixel(@x + x1, @y + y1, @color)
  Lime.pixel(@x + y1, @y + x1, @color)
  Lime.pixel(@x - y1, @y + x1, @color)
  Lime.pixel(@x - x1, @y + y1, @color)
  Lime.pixel(@x - x1, @y - y1, @color)
  Lime.pixel(@x - y1, @y - x1, @color)
  Lime.pixel(@x + y1, @y - x1, @color)
  Lime.pixel(@x + x1, @y - y1, @color)
  if err <= 0
    y1 = y1 + 1
    err = err + (y1 * 2)
  end
  if err > 0
    x1 = x1 - 1
    err = err - (x1 * 2)
  end
end

constructors.name: new
constructors.doc:
Initializes new `Pixels` from a string.

Iterates through every character of *pixels* and every time a color character
is found, it's replaced with its color.

Available color characters are:
* `'1'`: default
* `'0'`: black
* `'9'`: dark gray
* `'6'`: light gray
* `'r'`: red
* `'g'`: green
* `'b'`: blue
* `'y'`: yellow
* `'m'`: magenta
* `'c'`: cyan
* `'R'`: light red
* `'G'`: light green
* `'B'`: light blue
* `'Y'`: light yellow
* `'M'`: light magenta
* `'C'`: light cyan

Comments are also allowed in the string.

Example:

```
# A flower:
 RRR
RYYYR # Head
 RRR
  g
G g G
GGgGG # Stem
 GgG
  g
```

becomes:

![flower](https://i.imgur.com/XaxqEjB.png)

Raises `Error` when an invalid color character is found in *pixels*.

instance_methods.name: draw
instance_methods.doc: Inserts the pixels into the buffer.

def.name: draw
def.body:
x, y = 0, 0
@pixels.each do |pixel|
  case pixel
  when :newline
    y = y + 1
    x = 0
  when :skip
    x = x + 1
  else
    Lime.pixel(@x + x, @y + y, pixel.as(Colorize::ColorRGB | Colorize::ColorANSI))
    x = x + 1
  end
end

instance_methods.name: map
instance_methods.doc:
Invokes the given block for each of the pixels, replacing the pixel with the pixel returned by the block.
The block must return a `Tuple(UInt8, UInt8, UInt8)`.

```
# Invert colors of an image:
image.map { |pixel| {255u8 - pixel.red, 255u8 - pixel.green, 255u8 - pixel.blue} }
```
instance_methods.summary: Invokes the given block for each of the pixels, replacing the pixel with the pixel returned by the block.

def.name: map
def.body:
@pixels.map! do |pixel|
  if pixel.is_a?(Colorize::ColorRGB | Colorize::ColorANSI)
    Colorize::ColorRGB.new(*yield pixel)
  else
    pixel
  end
end

constants.name: Default
constants.doc:
The default rectangle type. It looks like this:
```text
┌────┐
│    │
└────┘
```

Like the default type but with doubled lines:
